message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Evolutionary Games and the Replicator Dynamics
Paper Abstract: This Element introduces the replicator dynamics for symmetric and asymmetric games where the strategy sets are metric spaces. Under this hypothesis the replicator dynamics evolves in a Banach space of finite signed measures. The authors provide a general framework to study the stability of the replicator dynamics for evolutionary games in this Banach space. This allows them to establish a relation between Nash equilibria and the stability of the replicator for normal a form games applicable to oligopoly models, theory of international trade, public good models, the tragedy of commons, and War of attrition game among others. They also provide conditions to approximate the replicator dynamics on a space of measures by means of a finite-dimensional dynamical system and a sequence of measure-valued Markov processes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about symmetric games in game theory:

## Definition

In game theory, a symmetric game is a game where the payoffs for playing a particular strategy depend only on the other strategies employed, not on who is playing them. More specifically, if one can change the identities of the players without changing the payoff to the strategies, then a game is symmetric.

## Types of Symmetry

Ordinally symmetric games are games that are symmetric with respect to the ordinal structure of the payoffs. A game is quantitatively symmetric if and only if it is symmetric with respect to the exact payoffs. Additionally, a partnership game is a symmetric game where both players receive identical payoffs for any strategy set. That is, the payoff for playing strategy a against strategy b receives the same payoff as playing strategy b against strategy a.

## Common Examples

The standard representations of chicken, the Prisoner's Dilemma, and the Stag hunt are all symmetric games.

## Mathematical Properties

Nash (1951) shows that every finite symmetric game has a symmetric mixed strategy Nash equilibrium. Furthermore, every two-strategy symmetric game has a (not necessarily symmetric) pure strategy Nash equilibrium.

Notably, only 12 out of the 144 ordinally distinct 2x2 games are symmetric. However, many of the commonly studied 2x2 games are at least ordinally symmetric.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the search results for "asymmetric game":

## Game Theory Definition

In game theory, a symmetric game is a game where the payoffs for playing a particular strategy depend only on the other strategies employed, not on who is playing them. By contrast, an asymmetric game would be one where player identity affects payoffs, or where players have different strategic options available to them.

## Board Games and Video Games

Asymmetric multiplayer video games are games in which one player or faction of players play the game differently from the other(s). Examples include:

- **Dunsany's Chess**: An asymmetric chess variant in which Black has the standard chess army and White has 32 pawns.

- **Evolve**: An asymmetrical multiplayer game where five players—four playing as hunters and one as the monster—battle against each other on an industrialized alien planet.

These types of asymmetric games have become increasingly popular in modern game design, offering unique multiplayer experiences where players have fundamentally different objectives and capabilities.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Manipulated Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulated_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Strong Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Talk:Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Epsilon-equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epsilon-equilibrium"},{"title":"Coalition-proof Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition-proof_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Correlated equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlated_equilibrium"},{"title":"Nash equilibrium computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium_computation"},{"title":"Mertens-stable equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mertens-stable_equilibrium"},{"title":"Markov perfect equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_perfect_equilibrium"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Nash equilibrium:

## Definition

Nash equilibrium is achieved when no player can improve their outcome by changing their decision, assuming the other players' choices remain unchanged. More formally, in a game with multiple players, a strategy profile is a Nash equilibrium if each player's strategy is their best response to the other players' strategies.

## Key Concepts

Game theorists use Nash equilibrium to analyze the outcome of the strategic interaction of several decision makers, where the outcome for each decision-maker depends on the decisions of the others as well as their own.(no content)The fundamental insight is that one cannot predict the choices of multiple decision makers by analyzing those decisions in isolation; instead, one must ask what each player would do taking into account what the player expects the others to do.

## Historical Background

The idea of Nash equilibrium dates back to the time of Cournot, who in 1838 applied it to his model of competition in an oligopoly.(no content)John Nash showed that there is a Nash equilibrium, possibly in mixed strategies, for every finite game.

## Applications

The concept has been used to analyze hostile situations such as wars and arms races, how conflict may be mitigated by repeated interaction, the extent to which people with different preferences can cooperate, whether they will take risks to achieve cooperative outcomes, the adoption of technical standards, and the occurrence of bank runs and currency crises.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"International trade theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_trade_theory"},{"title":"New trade theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_trade_theory"},{"title":"Category:International trade theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:International_trade_theory"},{"title":"International trade - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_trade"},{"title":"Strategic trade theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_trade_theory"},{"title":"Gottfried Haberler - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Haberler"},{"title":"Trade promotion (international trade) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_promotion_(international_trade)"},{"title":"Comparative advantage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_advantage"},{"title":"Absolute gain (international relations) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_gain_(international_relations)"},{"title":"Leontief paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leontief_paradox"}]

Here are the key results from the web search on international trade theory:

## Overview

International trade theory is a sub-field of economics which analyzes the patterns of international trade, its origins, and its welfare implications.

## Major Theoretical Frameworks

**Classical Theories:**

Adam Smith describes trade taking place as a result of countries having absolute advantage in production of particular goods, relative to each other, where absolute advantage refers to the instance where one country can produce a unit of a good with less labor than another country.(no content)The Ricardian theory of comparative advantage became a basic constituent of neoclassical trade theory.(no content)The Ricardian model focuses on comparative advantage, which arises due to differences in technology or natural resources.

**Heckscher-Ohlin Model:**

In the early 1900s, a theory of international trade was developed by two Swedish economists, Eli Heckscher and Bertil Ohlin, which has subsequently become known as the Heckscher–Ohlin model (H–O model).(no content)The results of the H–O model are that the pattern of international trade is determined by differences in factor endowments, and it predicts that countries will export those goods that make intensive use of locally abundant factors and will import goods that make intensive use of factors that are locally scarce.

**Modern Theories:**

New trade theory (NTT) is a collection of economic models in international trade theory which focuses on the role of increasing returns to scale and network effects, which were originally developed in the late 1970s and early 1980s.(no content)The Gravity model of trade presents a more empirical analysis of trading patterns, and in its basic form, predicts trade based on the distance between countries and the interaction of the countries' economic sizes.

Web search results for query: "replicator dynamics"

Links: [{"title":"Replicator equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_equation"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Replicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator"},{"title":"Chicken (game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicken_(game)"},{"title":"Replicator (cellular automaton) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(cellular_automaton)"},{"title":"Replicator (United States military) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(United_States_military)"},{"title":"Self-replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replication"},{"title":"Replicator (Star Trek) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(Star_Trek)"},{"title":"Self-replicating machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replicating_machine"},{"title":"DNA replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_replication"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about replicator dynamics:

## Definition

Replicator dynamics (or the replicator equation) is a type of dynamical system used in evolutionary game theory to model how the frequency of strategies in a population changes over time.(no content)It is a simple model of strategy change where a strategy which does better than the average increases in frequency at the expense of strategies that do worse than the average.

## Mathematical Properties

It is a deterministic, monotone, non-linear, and non-innovative dynamic that captures the principle of natural selection.(no content)Since the replicator equation is non-linear, an exact solution is difficult to obtain, so the equation is usually analyzed in terms of stability.

## Assumptions and Forms

The replicator dynamics models heredity but not mutation, and assumes asexual reproduction for the sake of simplicity.(no content)Continuous replicator equations assume infinite populations, continuous time, complete mixing and that strategies breed true.

## Applications

Replicator dynamics have been widely applied in fields such as biology (to study evolution and population dynamics), economics (to analyze bounded rationality and strategy evolution), and machine learning (particularly in multi-agent systems and reinforcement learning).

Web search results for query: "Markov process"

Links: [{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Markov property - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_property"},{"title":"Markov renewal process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_renewal_process"},{"title":"Examples of Markov chains - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Examples_of_Markov_chains"},{"title":"Gauss–Markov process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauss–Markov_process"},{"title":"Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_model"},{"title":"Piecewise-deterministic Markov process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piecewise-deterministic_Markov_process"},{"title":"Category:Markov processes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Markov_processes"},{"title":"Hidden Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model"}]

Here are the search results for "Markov process":

## Overview

A Markov process is a stochastic process that satisfies the Markov property (sometimes characterized as "memorylessness"). In probability theory and statistics, a Markov chain or Markov process is a stochastic process describing a sequence of possible events in which the probability of each event depends only on the state attained in the previous event.(no content)Informally, this may be thought of as, "What happens next depends only on the state of affairs now."

## Key Characteristics

It is a process for which predictions can be made regarding future outcomes based solely on its present state and—most importantly—such predictions are just as good as the ones that could be made knowing the process's full history. In other words, conditional on the present state of the system, its future and past states are independent.

## Types of Markov Processes

A countably infinite sequence, in which the chain moves state at discrete time steps, gives a discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC). A continuous-time process is called a continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC).

## Historical Background and Applications

Markov processes are named in honor of the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov.(no content)Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes. They provide the basis for general stochastic simulation methods known as Markov chain Monte Carlo, which are used for simulating sampling from complex probability distributions, and have found application in areas including Bayesian statistics, biology, chemistry, economics, finance, information [content cut off].

Here are the search results for "oligopoly economics":

## Definition and Overview

Oligopoly is a market structure in which there are few sellers of a good, and in an oligopoly, the companies interact strategically.

## Key Characteristics

The main characteristics of an oligopoly are: a few sellers and many buyers; homogenous or differentiated products; and high barriers to entry. Firms in an oligopoly market structure tend to set prices rather than adopt them, with important barriers to entry including government licenses, economies of scale, patents, access to expensive and complex technology, and strategic actions by incumbent firms designed to discourage or destroy nascent firms.

## Competition Strategies

Non-price competition often occurs in oligopoly, where few firms dominate the market, and due to the few firms in the market, these firms tend to compete in non-price measures to distinguish themselves. Oligopolies tend to compete on terms other than price, as non-price competition, such as promotional efforts, is less risky.

## Theoretical Models

The Cournot model and Bertrand model are the most well-known models in oligopoly theory, and the Cournot-Bertrand model is a hybrid of these two models that was first developed by Bylka and Komar in 1976.

## Real-World Examples

Many industries have been cited as oligopolistic, including civil aviation, electricity providers, the telecommunications sector, rail freight markets, food processing, funeral services, sugar refining, beer making, pulp and paper making, and automobile manufacturing.

Web search results for query: "war of attrition game theory"

Links: [{"title":"War of attrition (game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_attrition_(game)"},{"title":"Attrition warfare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attrition_warfare"},{"title":"Attrition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attrition"},{"title":"Talk:War of attrition (game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:War_of_attrition_(game)"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_Game_Theory"},{"title":"War of Attrition (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_Attrition_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Chicken (game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicken_(game)"},{"title":"Talk:List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"War of Attrition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_Attrition"}]

## War of Attrition in Game Theory

I found comprehensive information about the war of attrition in game theory. Here are the key findings:

### Basic Definition

In game theory, the war of attrition is a dynamic timing game in which players choose a time to stop, and fundamentally trade off the strategic gains from outlasting other players and the real costs expended with the passage of time.

### Historical Development

The model was originally formulated by John Maynard Smith; a mixed evolutionarily stable strategy (ESS) was determined by Bishop & Cannings.

### How It Works

Two players are involved in a dispute. Each player chooses when to concede the object to the other player. Time is valuable, each player uses one unit of utility per period of time. 

### Auction Perspective

The war of attrition is an auction in which both players pay the lower bid (an all-pay second price auction). The bids are assumed to be the duration which the player is willing to persist in making a costly threat display. Both players accrue costs while displaying at each other, the contest ends when the individual making the lower bid quits.

### Key Strategic Insight

In the war of attrition any strategy that is unwavering and predictable is unstable, because it will ultimately be displaced by a mutant strategy which relies on the fact that it can best the existing predictable strategy by investing an extra small delta of waiting resource to ensure that it wins.

This makes the war of attrition distinct from other game theory models in its emphasis on the costs of time and the need for unpredictable strategies.

Links: [{"title":"Tragedy of the commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons"},{"title":"CC–PP game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CC–PP_game"},{"title":"Elinor Ostrom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elinor_Ostrom"},{"title":"Garrett Hardin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garrett_Hardin"},{"title":"Tragedy in the Commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_in_the_Commons"},{"title":"Commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commons"},{"title":"Talk:Tragedy of the commons/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Tragedy_of_the_commons/Archive_1"},{"title":"Category:Tragedy of the commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Tragedy_of_the_commons"},{"title":"Tragedy of the anticommons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_anticommons"},{"title":"The Tragedy of the Commons (Fargo) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tragedy_of_the_Commons_(Fargo)"}]

Here are the key findings about the tragedy of the commons:

## Definition

The tragedy of the commons is the concept that, if many people enjoy unfettered access to a finite, valuable resource, such as a pasture, they will tend to overuse it and may end up destroying its value altogether.(no content)Even if some users exercised voluntary restraint, the other users would merely replace them, the predictable result being a "tragedy" for all.

## Historical Origins

The metaphorical term is the title of a 1968 essay by ecologist Garrett Hardin. However, the concept itself did not originate with Hardin but rather extends back to classical antiquity, being discussed by Aristotle. More specifically, Hardin's essay cited an 1833 pamphlet by the English economist William Forster Lloyd which included an example of herders sharing a common parcel of land, which would lead to overgrazing.

## How It Works

Hardin theorized that if each herdsman sharing a piece of common grazing land made the individually rational economic decision of increasing the number of cattle he keeps on the land, the collective effect would deplete or destroy the commons. In other words, multiple individuals—acting independently and rationally consulting their own self-interest—will ultimately deplete a shared limited resource, even when it is clear that it is not in anyone's long-term interest for this to happen.

## Modern Perspectives

Ostrom believes that the "tragedy" in such situations isn't inevitable, as Hardin thought. Instead, if the herders decide to cooperate with one another, monitoring each other's use of the land and enforcing rules for managing it, they can avoid the tragedy.

Links: [{"title":"Tragedy of the commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons"},{"title":"CC–PP game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CC–PP_game"},{"title":"Elinor Ostrom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elinor_Ostrom"},{"title":"Garrett Hardin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garrett_Hardin"},{"title":"Tragedy in the Commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_in_the_Commons"},{"title":"Commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commons"},{"title":"Talk:Tragedy of the commons/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Tragedy_of_the_commons/Archive_1"},{"title":"Category:Tragedy of the commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Tragedy_of_the_commons"},{"title":"Tragedy of the anticommons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_anticommons"},{"title":"The Tragedy of the Commons (Fargo) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tragedy_of_the_Commons_(Fargo)"}]

Here are the key findings about the tragedy of the commons:

## Definition

The tragedy of the commons is the concept that, if many people enjoy unfettered access to a finite, valuable resource, such as a pasture, they will tend to overuse it and may end up destroying its value altogether.(no content)Even if some users exercised voluntary restraint, the other users would merely replace them, the predictable result being a "tragedy" for all.

## Historical Origins

The metaphorical term is the title of a 1968 essay by ecologist Garrett Hardin. However, the concept itself did not originate with Hardin but rather extends back to classical antiquity, being discussed by Aristotle. More specifically, Hardin's essay cited an 1833 pamphlet by the English economist William Forster Lloyd which included an example of herders sharing a common parcel of land, which would lead to overgrazing.

## How It Works

Hardin theorized that if each herdsman sharing a piece of common grazing land made the individually rational economic decision of increasing the number of cattle he keeps on the land, the collective effect would deplete or destroy the commons. In other words, multiple individuals—acting independently and rationally consulting their own self-interest—will ultimately deplete a shared limited resource, even when it is clear that it is not in anyone's long-term interest for this to happen.

## Modern Perspectives

Ostrom believes that the "tragedy" in such situations isn't inevitable, as Hardin thought. Instead, if the herders decide to cooperate with one another, monitoring each other's use of the land and enforcing rules for managing it, they can avoid the tragedy.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "public goods problem"

Links: [{"title":"Public good - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_good"},{"title":"Collective action problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action_problem"},{"title":"Free-rider problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free-rider_problem"},{"title":"Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Common good (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_good_(economics)"},{"title":"Global public good - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_public_good"},{"title":"Collective action theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action_theory"},{"title":"Lindahl tax - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindahl_tax"},{"title":"Samuelson condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuelson_condition"},{"title":"Goods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goods"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of the public goods problem:

## Definition and Core Characteristics

Public goods are defined by two characteristics: non-excludability and non-rivalry—meaning that anyone can benefit from them and one person's use of them does not hinder another person's use of them.

## The Free-Rider Problem

Public goods problems are often closely related to the "free-rider" problem, in which people not paying for the good may continue to access it.(no content)Consumers can take advantage of public goods without contributing sufficiently to their creation. If too many consumers decide to "free-ride", private costs exceed private benefits and the incentive to provide the good or service through the market disappears. The market thus fails to provide a good or service for which there is a need.

## Consequences

The good may be under-produced, overused or degraded.(no content)It is generally accepted by mainstream economists that the market mechanism will under-provide public goods, so these goods have to be produced by other means, including government provision.

## Examples

An example is public broadcasting that relies on contributions from viewers. Since no single viewer is essential for providing the service, viewers can reap the benefits of the service without paying anything for it. If not enough people contribute, the service cannot be provided.

## Theoretical Framework

The most prominent modern interpretation of the collective action problem can be found in Mancur Olson's 1965 book The Logic of Collective Action.(no content)Olson argued that individual rationality does not necessarily result in group rationality, as members of a group may have conflicting interests that do not represent the best interests of the overall group. Olson further argued that in the case of a pure public good that is both nonrival and nonexcludable, one contributor tends to reduce their contribution to the public good as others contribute more.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

- Public good models
